column2: DUTY: To promote a comprehensive health service
column3:
Duty to promote a comprehensive health service, designed to secure the improvement in the physical and mental health of people in England and the prevention, diagnoses and treatment of illness.

NHS England is subject to this duty alongside the Secretary of State, except for that part of the health service that is delivered in pursuit of public health functions of the Secretary of State or local authorities.
(NHS Act 2006, S1H(2))
column6: POWER:  To do anything that will facilitate the discharge of functions under the 2006 Act
column7:
Power for CCGs to do anything calculated to facilitate, or is conducive or incidental to the discharge of any function given to CCGs under the 2006 Act.
(NHS Act 2006, section 2)
column10: DUTY:  To promote individual wellbeing
column11:
When carrying out their functions under the Care Act 2014, local authorities must act in a way to promote an individual’s well-being.  Well-being includes physical and mental health, as well as broader factors like participation in work or training.

(Care Act 2014, s1)
column14: DUTY:  To promote individual wellbeing
column15:
When carrying out their functions under the Care Act 2014, local authorities must act in a way to promote an individual’s well-being.  Well-being includes physical and mental health, as well as broader factors like participation in work or training.

(Care Act 2014, s1)
column18: DUTY (NHS Trust Only): Provision of NHS goods and services
column19: NHS Trusts provide goods and services for the purposes of the NHS. (NHS Act 2006, s25)
column22: POWER: Process data for legitmate interest
column23: Processing shall be lawful for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller, however, does not apply for public authorities, for the performance of their public tasks.  (GDPR, Article 6(1)(f))

column2: POWER:  To do anything that will facilitate the discharge of functions under the 2006 Act
column3:
NHS England has the power to do anything calculated to facilitate, or is conducive or incidental to the discharge of any function given to NHS England under the 2006 Act.

This includes, for example, the carrying out of counter-fraud/ security measures.

(NHS Act 2006, section 2, NHS Act 2006, section 195(2) regarding counter-fraud/ security measures)
column6: DUTY: To commission hospital accommodation, medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance service
column7:
A  CCG must arrange for the provision of health services to meet the reasonable requirements of the persons for whom it has responsibility. These health services include:
• hospital accommodation
• any other accommodation needed for the delivery of services under the NHS Act 2006
• medical, ophthalmic, nursing and ambulance services.
• services for the care of pregnant women, women who are breastfeeding and young children
• other services or facilities for the prevention of illness, the care of persons suffering from illness and the after-care of persons who have suffered from illness
• other services needed for the diagnosis and treatment of illness

If there is overlap between this duty on CCGs and any duty on NHS England to provide services, then the CCG duty will not apply.

(NHS Act 2006, section 3)
column10: POWER: To provide preventative services
column11:
A local authority must provide services that:

• Help prevent or delay the need of adults for care and support
• Help prevent or delay the need of carers for support
• Reduce the need of adults for care and support
• Reduce the needs of carers for support

When doing this, a local authority must have regard to services/ resources already available in its area and consider whether these services/ resource can be used.  This will include any services offered by NHS England and/ or CCGs.

(Care Act 2014, s2)
column14: POWER: To provide preventative services
column15:
A local authority must provide services that:

• Help prevent or delay the need of adults for care and support
• Help prevent or delay the need of carers for support
• Reduce the need of adults for care and support
• Reduce the needs of carers for support

When doing this, a local authority must have regard to services/ resources already available in its area and consider whether these services/ resource can be used.  This will include any services offered by NHS England and/ or CCGs.

(Care Act 2014, s2)
column18: DUTY (NHS Trust Only): Delivery of services set out in Establishment Order (various)
column19:
NHS Trusts must deliver the services set out in their Establishment Order.  This will usually refer to the locations at which the Trust is to deliver NHS Services.  It may also include reference to teaching and research facilities

(NHS Act 2006, section 25, Various Establishment Orders – there is one for each NHS Trust)

column2: DUTY: To provide high secure  psychiatric services
column3:
NHS England has a duty to provide secure psychiatric premises for people who are liable to be detained under the Mental Health Act 1983 and need treating in a high security environment.
(NHS Act 2006, S4, HSCA 2012, S16)
column6: POWER: To commission certain other health services
column7:
Each CCG provide the healthcare services that it considers appropriate for the purposes of the health service that relate to securing improvement in –
(a) the physical and mental health of persons for whom it has responsibility; or
(b) the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of illness in those persons.
These services cannot include high security psychiatric services that NHS England has to deliver, or any services that the Secretary of State has ordered NHS England to deliver.

(NHS Act 2006, section 3A)
column10: DUTY: To carry out functions with the aim of integrating services
column11: Local authorities must carry out their care functions with a view "to ensuring the integration of care and support provision with health provision and health-related provision”.  Health-related provision excludes social care services. (Care Act 2014, s3)
column14: DUTY: To carry out functions with the aim of integrating services
column15: Local authorities must carry out their care functions with a view "to ensuring the integration of care and support provision with health provision and health-related provision”.  Health-related provision excludes social care services. (Care Act 2014, s3)
column18: DUTY (NHS Trust Only): Efficient delivery of functions
column19: An NHS Trust must exercise its functions effectively, efficiently and economically. (NHS Act 2006, s26)

column2: POWER: Performance of functions outside England
column3:
NHS England can arrange for services to be provided outside of England if this relates to:

• holidays for patients
• the transfer of patients to or from Scotland, Northern Ireland, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands, or
• the return of patients who have received treatment in England and Wales, to countries or territories outside the British Islands (including for this purpose the Republic of Ireland).

 (NHS Act 2006 s6)
column6: POWER: Arrange of performance of functions outside England
column7:
A CCG can arrange for services to be provided outside of England if this relates to:

• holidays for patients
• the transfer of patients to or from Scotland, Northern Ireland, the Isle of Man or the Channel Islands, or
• the return of patients who have received treatment in England and Wales, to countries or territories outside the British Islands (including for this purpose the Republic of Ireland).

(NHS Act 2006 s6 (1A))
column10: DUTY:  To provide information and advice about care and support
column11: Local authorities must establish and maintain a service for providing people in its area with information and advice relating to care and support for adults and support for carers. (Care Act 2014, s4)
column14: DUTY:  To provide information and advice about care and support
column15: Local authorities must establish and maintain a service for providing people in its area with information and advice relating to care and support for adults and support for carers. (Care Act 2014, s4)
column18: DUTY (NHS FT Only): Delivery of NHS goods and services
column19: The principal purpose of an NHS Foundation Trust is to  provide goods and services for the purposes of the NHS in England   (NHS Act 2006, s43(1))

column2: DUTY: To exercise relevant public health functions
column3:
The Secretary of State for Health can require NHS England to carry out some of his public health tasks.  The Secretary of State’s requirements are set out annually in the Public Health Functions Agreement.

More detail on what public health functions NHS England carries out under the agreement can be found here:
https://www.england.nhs.uk/commissioning/pub-hlth-res/

(NHS Act 2006 , section 7A)
column6: POWER: To assist Secretary of State in providing health services and exercising public health functions
column7:
The Secretary of State for Health can require a CCG to carry out some of his public health tasks.

(NHS Act 2006, section 7A)
column10: DUTY:  To co-operate with NHS bodies when delivering care functions
column11: A local authority must co-operate with NHS bodies in its area, and vice versa, when providing care services to adults, support services to carers and other related services. (Care Act 2014, s6)
column14: DUTY:  To co-operate with NHS bodies when delivering care functions
column15: A local authority must co-operate with NHS bodies in its area, and vice versa, when providing care services to adults, support services to carers and other related services. (Care Act 2014, s6)
column18: POWER (NHS FT Only): Provision of  goods/ services related to healthcare or public health
column19:
An NHS Foundation Trust may provide goods and services for any purposes related to:

• the provision of services to individuals for or in connection with the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of illness
• the promotion and protection of public health

(NHS Act 2006, s43(2))

column2: POWER: To assist SoS in providing health services and exercising public health functions
column3:
SSection 12 empowers the Secretary of State to make arrangements with any person or body to provide, or assist in providing, anything that the Secretary of State has a duty or power to provide, or arrange for the provision of, under section 2A or 2B or Schedule 1 of the 2006 Act, as amended (the Secretary of State’s duty as to the protection of public health and the improvement of public health respectively).

(NHS Act 2006, S12, HSCA 2012, s22)
column6: POWER: To make direct payments to patients
column7:
A CCG can secure the delivery of services to a patient by making direct payments to the patient/ their nominee for the services.  A CCG can work with other organisations to deliver direct payments, including voluntary organisations.

Further detail is set out in regulations.

(NHS Act 2006, section 12A, section 12D
National Health Service (Direct Payments) Regulations 2013)
column10: DUTY: To improve the well-being of and reduce inequalities for children
column11: A local authority must improve the well-being of and reduce inequalities between children in its area, including health inequalities. (Childcare Act 2006, s1)
column14: DUTY:  To meet the care and support needs of eligible adults
column15:
In certain circumstances, a local authority must meet the care and support needs of individuals meeting the eligibility criteria.

This cannot include providing services that the NHS is required to deliver unless:
• doing so is ancillary to other services that are being provided; and
• the service of a nature that the local authority could be expected to provide.

(Care Act 2014, s18)
column18: POWER (NHS FT Only): Income generation
column19: An NHS Foundation Trust can carry on additional activities to generate additional income that helps it better deliver NHS care. (NHS Act 2006, s43(3))

column2: POWER: To make direct payments to patients
column3:
NHS England can secure the delivery of services to a patient by making a direct payment to the patient/ their nominee for the services.  NHS England can work with other organisations to deliver direct payments, including voluntary organisations.

Further detail is set out in regulations.

(NHS Act 2006, section 12A
National Health Service (Direct Payments) Regulations 2013)
column6: DUTY:  To exercise any functions delegated to the CCG by the Secretary of State
column7: The Secretary of State duties under the NHS Act 2006 can be delegated to CCGs. (NHS Act 2006, section 13Z)
column10: DUTY:  To co-operate with NHS England and CCGs when assessing the risks posed by offenders
column11:
Local authorities must make arrangements for managing the risks posed by some offenders.  In doing so they must co-operate with NHS England and CCGs.
(Criminal Justice Act 2003, section 325)
column14: POWER:  To meet the care and support needs of eligible adults
column15:
In certain circumstances, a local authority has discretion as to whether it meets the care and support needs of individuals meeting the eligibility criteria if the section 18 duty does not apply.

This cannot include providing services that the NHS is required to deliver unless:

• doing so is ancillary to other services that are being provided; and
• the service of a nature that the local authority could be expected to provide.

(Care Act 2014, s19)
column18: POWER (NHS FT Only):  To charge for accommodation or extra services
column19: An NHS Foundation Trust may charge patients for accommodation or non-NHS services. (NHS Act 2006, s44)

column2: DUTY: To exercise functions efficiently
column3:
NHS England must exercise its functions effectively, efficiently and economically.
(NHS Act 2006, s13D)
column6: DUTY: Exercise its functions efficiently
column7: Duty to exercise its functions effectively, efficiently and economically.  (NHS Act 2006, s14Q)
column10: DUTIES:  To deliver education services (various)
column11: Local authorities are subject to various duties under different legislation to provide education services. (Education Act 1996, section 578)
column14: DUTY:  To meet the support needs of eligible carers
column15:
In certain circumstances, a local authority must meet the support needs of carers meeting the eligibility criteria.

This cannot include providing services that the NHS is required to deliver unless:

• doing so is ancillary to other services that are being provided; and
• the service of a nature that the local authority could be expected to provide.

(Care Act 2014, s20)
column18: POWER (NHS FT Only): General power
column19: An NHS Foundation Trust can do anything that appears to it to be necessary or expedient for the purpose of or in connection with its functions. (NHS Act 2006, s47)

column2: DUTY: To secure continuous improvement in the quality of services
column3:
Duty on NHS England to exercise its functions with a view to securing continuous improvement in the quality of health and public health services provided to individuals.
(NHS Act 2006, S13E, HSCA 2012 S23)
column6: DUTY: Securing continuous improvement in quality of services provided to individuals
column7: Duty on CCGs to exercise their functions with a view to securing continuous improvement in the quality of health services provided to individuals  (NHS Act 2006, s14R)
column10: DUTY: Eliminate discrimination, harassment and victimisation and advance equality of opportunity
column11:
There is a duty for local authorities to have due regard to the need to:

• eliminate unlawful discrimination, harassment and victimisation,
• advance equality of opportunity between persons who share a relevant “protected characteristic” (e.g. ethnicity, gender) and persons who do not and
• foster good relations between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not.

(Equalities Act 2010, s149, schedule 19, part 1.)
column14: POWER:  To meet the support needs of eligible carers
column15:
In certain circumstances, a local authority has discretion as to whether it meets the support needs of individuals meeting the eligibility criteria if the section 20 duty does not apply.

This cannot include providing services that the NHS is required to deliver unless:

• doing so is ancillary to other services that are being provided; and
• the service of a nature that the local authority could be expected to provide.

(Care Act 2014, s20)
column18: DUTY (NHS FT Only): Efficient exercise of functions
column19: An NHS Foundation Trust must exercise its functions effectively, efficiently and economically. (NHS Act 2006, s63)

column2: DUTY:  To reduce health inequalities
column3:
When carrying out its functions NHS England must have regard to the need to:
• reduce inequalities in relation to accessing health services
• reduce inequalities between patients that relate to the provision of healthcare services
(NHS Act 2006, section 13G)
column6: DUTY: Improving quality of primary medical services
column7: Duty to support NHS England to deliver NHS England’s duty secure continuous improvement in the quality of primary medical services. (NHS Act 2006, s14S HSCA 2012 s26)
column10: POWER:  To delegate to Health & Wellbeing Board
column11:
A local authority may arrange for a Health and Wellbeing Board established by it to exercise any functions that are usually carried out by the authority.  This does not apply to review and scrutiny functions.

(Health and Social Care Act 2012, section 196)
column14: POWER: To delegate some care functions under the Care Act 2014
column15:
Local authorities can delegate:
• their care and support functions under the Care Act 2014
• after care duties under section 117 of the Mental Health Act 1983

However, this does not include duties to promote integration and co-operate with other bodies, safeguarding and charging.  These cannot be delegated.

(Care Act 2014, s79)
column18: DUTY: NHS bodies to co-operate
column19: Duty for NHS bodies to co-operate with each other in exercising their functions  (NHS Act 2006, s72)

column2: DUTY: To promote integrated health services
column3:
NHS England has a duty to exercise its functions with a view to ensuring that health services are provided in an integrated way where this would:

• improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
• reduce inequalities of access to health services or
• reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

(NHS Act 2006, s13N(1))
column6: DUTY: Reduce health inequalities
column7:
When carrying out their functions CCGs must have regard to the need to:

• reduce inequalities in relation to accessing health services
• reduce inequalities between patients that relate to the provision of healthcare services

(NHS Act 2006, s14T)
column10: DUTY:  To share information
column11:
Local authorities must share information about patients for whom they are responsible with other health and social care organisations involved in their care.  (There are various carve outs.)  Note that this provision does not enable the sharing of data that breaches the Data Protection Act 1998, the common law duty of confidence or the common law duty of care.

(Health and Social Care Act 2012, section 251B)
column14: DUTY: To make direct payments to meet care needs
column15:
In some circumstances, local authorities must make direct payments to meet care needs.  Such needs can include after-care under the Mental Health Act 1983.  Detail is set out in regulations.
(Care Act 2014, sections 31, 32 and 33, Schedule 4
Care and Support (Direct Payments) Regulations 2014)
column18: POWER (NHS Trust Only): General power
column19: An NHS Trust can do anything that appears to it to be necessary or expedient for the purpose of or in connection with its functions. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 4, paragraph 14)

column2: DUTY: To promote integration between health services and health-related services
column3:
NHS England has a duty to exercise its functions with a view to ensuring that health services are integrated with the provision of health-related services and social care services where this would:

• improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
• reduce inequalities of access to health services or
• reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

“Health-related services” includes any service that has an effect on the health of individuals but that is not a health or social care service e.g. housing.

(NHS Act 2006, s13N(2))
column6: DUTY: To promote the involvement of each patient
column7:
CCGs must promote the involvement of patients, and their carers and representatives (if any), in decisions which relate to:

• the prevention or diagnosis of illness in the patients, or
• their care or treatment.

(NHS Act 2006, section 14U)
column10: POWER:  To supply/ receive goods and services
column11:
Local authorities may supply CCGs and NHS England with:

• goods or materials
• administrative, professional or technical services
• vehicles, plant or other apparatus, including associated staff.

This does not permit local authorities to construct any buildings

(Local Authorities (Goods and Services) Act 1970, section 1)
column14: DUTY: To improve the well-being of and reduce inequalities for children
column15: A local authority must improve the well-being of and reduce inequalities between children in its area, including health inequalities. (Childcare Act 2006, s1)
column18: POWER (NHS Trust Only):  Research
column19: An NHS Trust can undertake and commission research.  It can also make staff and facilities available to other people or organisations carrying out research. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 4, paragraph 16)

column2: DUTY:  to encourage the use of section 75 agreements between CCGs and local authorities
column3:
NHS England must also encourage CCGs to enter into arrangements with local authorities for the delivery of health services (section 75 agreements) where it considers that this would secure:

• the better integration of health services; or
• the better integration of health services with health-related services

And:

• improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
• reduce inequalities of access to health services or
• reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

(NHS Act 2006, section 13N(3))
column6: DUTY: Enabling patient choice
column7: CCGs must act with a view to enabling patients to make choices with respect to aspects of health services provided to them. (NHS Act 2006, section 14V)
column10: DUTY: To prepare a joint strategic needs assessment
column11: Local authorities must prepare a joint strategic needs assessment with the relevant local authority and a joint health and wellbeing strategy to meet those needs. (Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007, section 116 & 116A)
column14: DUTY:  To co-operate with NHS England and CCGs when assessing the risks posed by offenders
column15:
Local authorities must make arrangements for managing the risks posed by some offenders.  In doing so they must co-operate with NHS England and CCGs.
(Criminal Justice Act 2003, section 325)
column18: POWER (NHS Trust Only): Joint exercise of functions
column19: An NHS Trust can arrange to carry out its functions jointly with any other organisation. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 4, paragraph 18)

column2: POWER:  To generate income
column3:
NHS England has the power to raise additional income in some circumstances, provided this does not interfere to a significant extent with the performance by NHS England of its functions.

NHS England can raise extra income through:

• acquiring, producing, manufacturing or supplying goods
• acquiring land by agreement and management of the land
• providing instructions to any person
• developing and exploiting with intellectual property
• an appropriate action which will facilitate one of the above
• making appropriate charges relating to any such power as listed above.

(NHS Act 2006, s13W)
column6: DUTY: To promote innovation
column7: CCGs must promote innovation in the provision of health services, including innovative approaches to commissioning. (NHS Act 2006, s14X)
column10: DUTY:  To ensure the involvement of local people in decision-making
column11:
Local authorities must make contractual arrangements to:

• enable the involvement of local people in the commissioning, provision and scrutiny of local health and social care services
• obtain the views of local people about their need for and experience of local health and social care services.

(Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007, s221)
column14: DUTY:  To assess certain patients for eligibility for welfare provision
column15:
Local authorities must make arrangements to assess people who have been an in-patient for one period of at least six months for treatment of a mental disorder to assess whether they are eligible for welfare services.  They must co-operate with any CCG that is also carrying out an assessment.
(Disabled Persons (Services, Consultation and Representation) Act 1986, s7)
column18: POWER (NHS Trust Only): Charges for accommodation or extra services
column19: An NHS Trust may charge patients for accommodation or non-NHS services provided this does not interfere with NHS services.  In some cases approval is needed from the Department of Health. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 4, paragraph 19)

column2: DUTY: Enabling patient choice
column3:
NHS England must act with a view to enabling patients to make choices with respect to aspects of health services provided to them.
(NHS Act 2006, section 13I)
column6: DUTY: Research
column7: CCGs must promote research relevant to the health service and the use of such research in the health service. (NHS Act 2006, s14Y)
column10: POWER: To provide recreational facilities
column11: Local authorities may provide recreational facilities, for example sports centres, swimming pools, tennis courts, outdoor sports pitches.  This can include the provision of staff and facilities connected with any recreational facilities, like parking spaces and refreshment facilities. (Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976, s19)
column14: DUTIES:  To deliver education services (various)
column15: Local authorities are subject to various duties under different legislation to provide education services. (Education Act 1996, section 578)
column18: POWER (NHS Trust Only): Income generation

column2: DUTY: To promote innovation
column3:
NHS England must promote innovation in the provision of health services, including innovative approaches to commissioning.
(NHS Act 2006, s13K)
column6: DUTY: to promote integrated health services
column7:
CCGs have a duty to exercise their functions with a view to ensuring that health services are provided in an integrated way where this would:

• improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
• reduce inequalities of access to health services or
• reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

(NHS Act 2006, section 14Z1(1))
column10: POWER:  General power
column11:
Local authorities can generally do anything that an individual can do, subject to any limitations that:

• were in place before the Localism Act 2011 came into force; or
• were put in place after the Localism Act was passed and are expressly said to apply.

There are some other restrictions.

This power is intended to be very broad.  It can cover doing things for a commercial purpose i.e. to generate income and charging for services.

(Localism Act 2011, s1-4)
column14: DUTY: Eliminate discrimination, harassment and victimisation and advance equality of opportunity
column15:
There is a duty for local authorities to have due regard to the need to:

• eliminate unlawful discrimination, harassment and victimisation,
• advance equality of opportunity between persons who share a relevant “protected characteristic” (e.g. ethnicity, gender) and persons who do not and
• foster good relations between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not.

(Equalities Act 2010, s149, schedule 19, part 1.)
column18: DUTY: Eliminate discrimination, harassment and victimisation and advance equality of opportunity
column19:
Duty for NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts to have due regard to the need to:

• eliminate unlawful discrimination, harassment and victimisation,
• advance equality of opportunity between persons who share a relevant “protected characteristic” (e.g. ethnicity, gender) and persons who do not and
• foster good relations between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not.

(Equalities Act 2010, s149, schedule 19, part 1.)

column2: DUTY: To promote research
column3:
NHS England must promote research relevant to the health service and the use of such research in the health service.
(NHS Act 2006, s13L)
column6: DUTY: to promote integration between health services and health-related services
column7:
CCGs have a duty to exercise their functions with a view to ensuring that health services are integrated with the provision of health-related services and social care services where this would:

• improve quality of health services (including outcomes) or
• reduce inequalities of access to health services or
• reduce inequalities of outcomes achieved by health services

“Health-related services” includes any service that has an effect on the health of individuals but that is not a health or social care service e.g. housing.

(NHS Act 2006, s14Z(2))
column10: DUTY: Provide services to improve public health
column11:
Local Authorities must take appropriate steps for improving the health of people in its area.

Section 12 of the Act lists some of the steps to improve public health that local authorities and the Secretary of State are able to take, including:

• carrying out research into health improvement, providing information and advice (for example giving information to the public about healthy eating and exercise);
• providing facilities for the prevention or treatment of illness (such as smoking cessation clinics);
• providing financial incentives to encourage individuals to adopt healthier lifestyles (for instance by giving rewards to people for stopping smoking during pregnancy); and,
• providing assistance to help individuals minimise risks to health arising from their accommodation or environment (for example a local authority may wish to improve poor housing where this impacts on health).

(NHS Act 2006, section 2B)
column14: POWER:  To delegate to Health & Wellbeing Board
column15:
A local authority may arrange for a Health and Wellbeing Board established by it to exercise any functions that are usually carried out by the authority.  This does not apply to review and scrutiny functions.

(Health and Social Care Act 2012, section 196)
column18: DUTY: To share information
column19:
NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts must share information about patients for whom it is responsible with other health and social care organisations involved in their care.  (There are various carve outs.)  Note that this provision does not enable the sharing of data that breaches the Data Protection Act 1998, the common law duty of confidence or the common law duty of care

(Health and Social Care Act 2012, s251B)

column2: DUTY: Understand impact of commissioning decisions on provision of services to Welsh and Scottish residents
column3: NHS England must have regard to the likely impact of its commissioning decisions on the provision of health services to people who live in an area of Wales or Scotland that is close to the border with England.  (NHS Act 2006 s13O, s23  HSCA 2012)
column6: DUTY: Public and patient involvement
column7:
CCGs must involve the public and the patients in decisions including:

• the planning of commissioning arrangements
• decisions made that affect the manner services are delivered or the range of services provided

(NHS Act 2006, section 14Z2)
column10: DUTY: To provide for the medical inspection and treatment of pupils at local authority schools
column11:
Local authorities must provide for the medical inspection of pupils in attendance at local authority maintained schools and for medical treatment of such pupils.
(NHS Act 2006, section 5 and Schedule 1, paragraph 1 )
column14: DUTY:  To share information
column15:
Local authorities must share information about patients for whom they are responsible with other health and social care organisations involved in their care.  (There are various carve outs.)  Note that this provision does not enable the sharing of data that breaches the Data Protection Act 1998, the common law duty of confidence or the common law duty of care.

(Health and Social Care Act 2012, section 251B)
column18: DUTY: Public involvement
column19:
NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts must make arrangements for involving the public and patients in:

• the planning of services
• the development of proposals for changes in the way those services are provided
• decisions about the operations of those services

(NHS Act 2006, s242)

column2: DUTY: Public and patient involvement
column3:
NHS England must involve the public and the patients in decisions including:
• the planning of commissioning arrangements
• decisions made that affect the manner services are delivered or the range of services provided
(NHS Act 2006, s13Q)
column6: POWER: For a CCG to deliver services jointly with another CCG
column7: CCGs can exercise their functions jointly, or on behalf of one another.  This means that one CCG can take on the functions of another. (NHS Act 2006, section 14Z3)
column10: POWER:  To provide for the medical inspection and treatment of pupils at other schools
column11: Local authorities can provide for the medical inspection of some pupils who do not attend school or attend a school that is not maintained by the local authority. (NHS Act 2006, section 5 and Schedule 1, paragraph 2)
column14: POWER:  To supply/ receive goods and services
column15:
Local authorities may supply CCGs and NHS England with:

• goods or materials
• administrative, professional or technical services
• vehicles, plant or other apparatus, including associated staff.

This does not permit local authorities to construct any buildings

(Local Authorities (Goods and Services) Act 1970, section 1)
column18: DUTY: To help local authorities support children and families
column19: NHS Trusts and NHS Foundation Trusts have a duty to comply with any request from a local authority to help exercise any of its functions relating to support for children and families if compatible with their own functions. (Children Act 1989, s27)

column2: DUTY: To collect and analyse information relating to safety of services
column3:
NHS England may:
• Establish and operate systems for collecting and analysing information relating to the safety of the services provided by the health service.  Such information and analyses of it must be made available to other appropriate persons.
• Give advice and guidance, to such persons as it considers appropriate, for the purpose of maintaining and improving the safety of the services provided by the health service and monitor the effectiveness of the advice and guidance.
(NHS Act 2006, S13R, HSCA 2012, s23)
column6: POWER: For a CCG to deliver services jointly with a combined authority
column7: CCGs can exercise their functions jointly with a combined authority.  (A combined authority is type of group of local authorities.) (NHS Act 2006, s14Z3A)
column10: DUTY: To provide a public health advice service
column11:
Local authorities must provide or make arrangements to secure the provision of a public health advice service to CCGs.
(NHS Act 2006, s 6C, Local Authorities (Public Health Functions and Entry to Premises by Local Healthwatch Representatives) Regulations 2013 (SI 2013/351), regulation 7)
column14: DUTIES: Social care (various)
column15:
Local authorities are subject to various duties under different legislation to provide social care services.

(Local Authority Social Services Act 1970, Schedule 1)
column18: POWER: Be partnership organisations
column19: Ability for NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts to second/ offer the services of Trust/ Foundation Trust staff to local authorities and vice versa. (Local Government Act 1972 s113 (1A))

column2: POWER: To provide assistance and support to CCGs
column3:
NHS England may provide assistance or support to a CCG.  This can include the provision of information.
(NHS Act 2006, s14Z1)
column6: POWER: For a CCG to deliver services jointly with a Local Health Board
column7: CCGs can exercise their functions jointly with Local Health Boards.  (A Local Health Board is a public sector organisation in Wales that commissions healthcare services.) (NHS Act 2006, section 14Z4)
column10: DUTY: To provide health checks for eligible people
column11:
Local authorities have a duty to provide or make arrangements to provide for health checks for eligible people, depending upon age and health status. The regulations specify the type of information to be recorded. Local authorities must also provide information about dementia to older people.
(NHS Act 2006, s6C, Local Authorities (Public Health Functions and Entry to Premises by Local Healthwatch Representatives) Regulations 2013 (SI 2013/351),  regulation 4&5)
column14: DUTY: To prepare a joint strategic needs assessment
column15: Local authorities must prepare a joint strategic needs assessment with the relevant local authority and a joint health and wellbeing strategy to meet those needs. (Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007, section 116 & 116A)
column18: DUTY: To consider the economic, social and environmental benefits to be achieved through commissioning
column19: General duty on NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts to consider the economic, environmental and social benefits that can be achieved through commissioning.  (Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012, s1)

column2: DUTY:  Issue guidance on commissioning to CCGs
column3:
NHS England must publish guidance for CCGs on the discharge of their commissioning functions.
(NHS Act 2006, section 14Z8)
column6: POWER:  To generate income
column7:
A CCG has the power to raise additional income in some circumstances, provided this does not interfere to a significant extent with the performance by the group of its functions.

CCGs can raise extra income through:

• acquiring, producing, manufacturing or supplying goods
• acquiring land by agreement and management of the land
• providing instructions to any person
• developing and exploiting with intellectual property
• an appropriate action which will facilitate one of the above
• making appropriate charges relating to any such power as listed above.

(NHS Act 2006, s14Z5)
column10: DUTY: To provide information and advice to promote the preparation of health protection arrangements
column11:
Local authorities must provide information and advice about the development of local health protection arrangements to the following  organisations that are in or deliver public services in the local authority’s area:

• NHS bodies
• The police
• Fire & rescue authority
• District council (if applicable)
• Public Health England

Local authorities must also provide information and advice to organisations that are in or deliver public services in the local authority’s area if the organisation’s activities may be significantly affected by a threat to the health of individuals in the local authority area.  These organisations can include:

• Schools
• Social care providers
• Voluntary organisations
• Charities
• Businesses

Health protection arrangements can address the threat to health caused by infectious disease, environmental hazards and extreme weather events.

(NHS Act 2006, section 6C, Local Authorities (Public Health Functions and Entry to Premises by Local Healthwatch Representatives) Regulations 2013, regulation 8))
column14: DUTY:  To ensure the involvement of local people in decision-making
column15:
Local authorities must make contractual arrangements to:

• enable the involvement of local people in the commissioning, provision and scrutiny of local health and social care services
• obtain the views of local people about their need for and experience of local health and social care services.

(Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007, s221)
column18: POWER: To enter into section 75 agreements with CCGs, providers and local authorities
column19:
NHS Trusts and Foundation Trusts can carry out the “health related functions” of a local authority and a local authority can carry out the NHS functions of the NHS Trust/ Foundation Trust if it enters into an agreement with the local authority that complies with the regulations. These agreements are often called section 75 agreements.

In practice this means that NHS England can carry out the functions of other organisations.

These arrangements can only be made in relation to health functions and health related functions.  These terms are defined in detail in the regulations.  Details of what functions are being carried out by which organisation will be contained in the section 75 agreement itself.

(NHS Bodies and Local Authorities Partnership Arrangements Regulations 2000)

column2: DUTY:  To assess the performance of CCGs
column3:
Each year NHS England must assess the performance of each CCG.
(NHS Act 2006, section 14Z16)
column6: POWER: For NHS England to deliver CCG services instead of or jointly with a CCG
column7: CCGs can deliver their functions jointly with NHS England, or NHS England can deliver the functions on behalf of the CCG (NHS Act 2006, s14Z9)
column10: DUTY: To provide open access sexual health services
column11:
Local authorities must provide, or make arrangements to secure the provision of open access sexual health services in their area.

This includes the provision of contraceptive services.  (The provision of contraceptive services is a duty of the Secretary of State but local authorities are required to deliver this duty on behalf of the Secretary of State.)

There is no requirement to provide treatment and care to those infected with the HIV virus or vasectomy and sterilisation services.

(NHS Act 2006, section 6C, Local Authorities (Public Health Functions and Entry to Premises by Local Healthwatch Representatives) Regulations 2013 regulation 6)
column14: POWER: To provide recreational facilities
column15: Local authorities may provide recreational facilities, for example sports centres, swimming pools, tennis courts, outdoor sports pitches.  This can include the provision of staff and facilities connected with any recreational facilities, like parking spaces and refreshment facilities. (Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1976, s19)

column2: DUTY: To provide primary medical services
column3:
NHS England must secure the provision of primary medical services.
(NHS Act 2006, S83(1), HSCA 2012, Sched 4, p30)
column6: DUTY: Payments to providers to NHS England specification
column7: Duty to be adhere to any NHS England document published under section 14Z7 (payments to providers). (NHS Act 2006 s14Z7, HSCA s26)
column10: POWER: To assist the Department of Health in providing health services and exercising public health functions
column11: The Secretary of State for Health can require a local authority or a combined authority to carry out some of his public health tasks.  (NHS Act 2006, section 7A)
column14: POWER:  General power
column15:
Local authorities can generally do anything that an individual can do, subject to any limitations that:

• were in place before the Localism Act 2011 came into force; or
• were put in place after the Localism Act was passed and are expressly said to apply.

There are some other restrictions.

This power is intended to be very broad.  It can cover doing things for a commercial purpose i.e. to generate income and charging for services.

(Localism Act 2011, s1-4)

column2: DUTY: To provide primary ophthalmic services
column3:
NHS England must secure the provision of primary ophthalmic services, in accordance with detailed regulations.  This includes sight-testing.
(NHS Act 2007, S115)
column6: POWER: To enter into section 75 agreements with NHSE, CCGs, providers and local authorities
column7:
CCGs can enter into section 75 agreements with local authorities for the delivery of health services and health-related services.  This means that local authorities can carry out some of the functions of CCGs and vice versa.

(NHS Act 2006, section 75
NHS Bodies and Local Authorities Partnership Agreements 2000)
column10: DUTY: To assist the Department of Health in providing health services and exercising public health functions
column11:
Section 12 empowers the Secretary of State to make arrangements with any person or body to provide, or assist in providing, anything that the Secretary of State has a duty or power to provide, or arrange for the provision of, under section 2A or 2B (the Secretary of State’s duty as to the protection of public health and the improvement of public health respectively or Schedule 1 of the 2006 Act, as amended).
(NHS Act 2006, section 12)
column14: DUTY: Providing after care of patients with mental health problems
column15:
Local authorities must, together with the CCG and relevant voluntary agencies, arrange for the provision of after care for persons previously detained under the Mental Health Act, at the time that they cease to be detained. Such after care should be provided until the local social services authority is satisfied that such services are no longer required.

(Mental Health Act 1983, s117)

column2: DUTY: To provide pharmaceutical services
column3:
NHS England must make arrangements for the provision of pharmaceutical services, in accordance with various regulations.
(Schedule 4, paragraph 63, HSCA 2012). (NHS Act 2009, S126)
column6: POWER: To supply local authorities with goods, services and facilities
column7:
CCGs have the power to supply to local authorities (and such public bodies as the Secretary of State may determine) any goods or materials of a kind used in the health service.

They also have a power to make available to local authorities any facilities the provision of which is:

• arranged by the CCG, any facilities of the CCG, and
• the services of persons employed by the CCG (e.g. secondments).

CCGs can also arrange for the carrying out of maintenance work in connection with any land or building for the maintenance of which a local authority is responsible.

(NHS Act 2006, s80)
column10: DUTY:  To exercise any functions delegated to the local authority by the Secretary of State
column11:
The Secretary of State duties under the NHS Act 2006 can in some circumstances be delegated to local authorities and combined authorities.

(NHS Act 2006, section 13ZA)
column14: DUTY:  To make arrangements for independent mental health advocates
column15: Local authorities must make reasonable arrangements to make sure that independent mental health advocates are available to help certain types of patient. (Mental Health Act 1983, section 130A)

column2: POWER: To supply local authorities with goods, services and facilities
column3:
NHS England has the power to supply to local authorities (and such public bodies as the Secretary of State may determine) any goods or materials of a kind used in the health service.

It also has a power to make available to local authorities any facilities the provision of which is arranged by NHS England, any facilities of NHS England, and the services of persons employed by NHS England (e.g. secondments).

NHS England can also arrange for the carrying out of maintenance work in connection with any land or building for the maintenance of which a local authority is responsible.

(NHS Act 2006, s80)
column6: DUTY: To make CCG facilities available to local authorities
column7:
CCGs must make available to local authorities any services or facilities the provision of which is arranged by the CCG, the services of persons employed by the CCG, and any facilities of the CCG, so far as is reasonably necessary to enable local authorities to discharge their functions relating to social services, education and public health.

(NHS Act 2006, section 80(6A))
column10: DUTY:  To make services available to NHS bodies
column11: Each local authority must make services available to NHS England and CCGs acting in its area to help them discharge their functions under the NHS Act 2006.  However, a local authority only has to do what is reasonable and practicable. (NHS Act 2006, section 74(3))
column14: POWER: To make direct payments to patients
column15:
A local authority can secure the delivery of services to a patient by making direct payments to the patient/ their nominee for the services.  A local authority can work with other organisations to deliver direct payments, including voluntary organisations.

Further detail is set out in regulations.

(NHS Act 2006, section 12A, section 12D, National Health Service (Direct Payments) Regulations 2013)

column2: DUTY: To pay CCGs to meet their expenditure
column3:
Section 223G requires NHS England to make a contribution in each financial year to each CCG.
(NHS Act 2006, S223G, HSCA 2012, S27)
column6: DUTY:  To comply with Better Care Fund conditions
column7: CCGs must comply with any conditions attached to Better Care Funding. (NHS Act 2006, section 223GA)
column10: POWER: To enter into section 75 agreements with NHS England or local authorities
column11: Local authorities can enter into section 75 agreements with CCGs and/ or NHS England for the delivery of health services and health-related services.  This means that local authorities can carry out some of the functions of CCGs and/or NHS England and vice versa. (NHS Act 2006, s75, NHS Bodies and Local Authorities Partnership Agreements 2000)
column14: DUTY:  To exercise any functions delegated to the local authority by the Secretary of State
column15:
The Secretary of State duties under the NHS Act 2006 can in some circumstances be delegated to local authorities and combined authorities.

(NHS Act 2006, section 13ZA)

column2: POWER:  Integration funding
column3:
NHS England can require that CCGs put some of their funding into a pooled fund to spend on integration, and attach conditions to that funding.
(NHS Act 2006, s223GA)
column6: DUTY:  To not go in to deficit
column7: Each CCG has a duty to perform its functions for each financial year so as to ensure that its expenditure does not exceed its income for that year. (NHS Act 2006, s223H)
column10: POWER: To make payments to CCGs and NHS England
column11:
Local authorities can make payments to CCGs and/or NHS England, provided this is for one of the purposes set out in regulations.

(NHS Act 2006, section 76, NHS Bodies and Local Authorities (Partnership Arrangements, Care Trusts, Public Health and Local Healthwatch) Regulations 2012, Regulation 13)
column14: DUTY:  To make services available to NHS bodies
column15: Each local authority must make services available to NHS England and CCGs acting in its area to help them discharge their functions under the NHS Act 2006.  However, a local authority only has to do what is reasonable and practicable. (NHS Act 2006, section 74(3))

column2: POWER: To make payments to CCGs in respect of quality of services
column3:
Under section 223K, the NHSCB has the ability, after the end of a financial year, to make a payment to a CCG in respect of quality. Section 223K(2) specifies that at least one of the prescribed factors must be taken into account by the NHSCB when determining whether to make a payment under section 223K. These factors include:

• The quality of relevant services provided;
• Any improvement in quality in comparison to the previous financial years;
• Achievement of outcomes identified for the financial year.

NHS England has the ability, after the end of a financial year, to make a payment to a CCG in respect of quality. At least one of the following factors must be taken into account by the NHS England:

• The quality of relevant services provided
• Any improvement in quality in comparison to the previous financial years
• Outcomes for the financial year.

NHS England may also take into account either or both of the following factors:

• Relevant inequalities identified during the financial year
• Any reduction in relevant inequalities identified during that year in comparison to those identified during the previous financial years.

(NHS Act 2006, section 223K National Health Service (Clinical Commissioning Groups – Payments in Respect of Quality) Regulations 2013, SI 2013/474)
column6: DUTY: Take appropriate steps in an emergency
column7: Each CCG must take appropriate steps to secure that it is properly prepared for dealing with relevant emergencies. (NHS Act 2006 s252A and HSCA s46)
column10: DUTY: To co-operate with CCGs and NHS England
column11: Local authorities have a duty to cooperate with CCGs and NHS England. (NHS Act 2006, section 82)
column14: POWER: To enter into section 75 agreements with NHS England or local authorities
column15: Local authorities can enter into section 75 agreements with CCGs and/ or NHS England for the delivery of health services and health-related services.  This means that local authorities can carry out some of the functions of CCGs and/or NHS England and vice versa. (NHS Act 2006, s75, NHS Bodies and Local Authorities Partnership Agreements 2000)

column2: POWER: To make a contribution to local authority costs
column3:
NHS England can make payments to local authorities towards the costs incurred by local authorities regarding particular social services and housing functions.
(NHS Act 2006, section 256)
column6: POWER: To make a contribution to local authority costs
column7: CCGs can make payments to local authorities towards the costs incurred by local authorities regarding particular social services and housing functions. (NHS Act 2006, s256)
column10: DUTY:  To provide dental public health services
column11:
Local authorities must provide appropriate:
• oral health promotion programmes
• oral health surveys

(NHS Act 2006, s111, NHS Bodies and Local Authorities (Partnership Arrangements, Care Trusts, Public Health and Local Healthwatch) Regulations 2012)
column14: POWER: To make payments to CCGs and NHS England
column15:
Local authorities can make payments to CCGs and/or NHS England, provided this is for one of the purposes set out in regulations.

(NHS Act 2006, section 76, NHS Bodies and Local Authorities (Partnership Arrangements, Care Trusts, Public Health and Local Healthwatch) Regulations 2012, Regulation 13)

column2: POWER: To conduct research
column3:
NHS England may conduct, commission or assist the conduct of research into:

• any matters relating to the causation, prevention, diagnosis or treatment of illness; and
• any other matters connected with the health service that NHS England considers appropriate.

(NHS Act 2006, Sched 1 p13)
column6: POWER:  Provision of wheelchairs and vehicles
column7: A CCG may provide vehicles (including wheelchairs) to people who have a physical impairment that has a substantial and long-term adverse effect on their ability to carry out normal day-to-day activities. (NHS Act 2006 Schedule 1, paragraph 9)
column10: DUTY:  To scrutinise local healthcare arrangements
column11:
A local authority may review and scrutinise any matter relating to the planning, provision and operation of the health service in its area.

(NHS Act 2006, s244, Local Authority (Public Health, Health and Wellbeing Boards and Health Scrutiny) Regulations 2013, Part 4)
column14: DUTY: To co-operate with CCGs and NHS England
column15: Local authorities have a duty to cooperate with CCGs and NHS England. (NHS Act 2006, section 82)

column2: POWER: To obtain and analyse data
column3:
NHS England can obtain and analyse data or other information for any purpose connected with the exercise of its functions in relation to the health service
(NHS Act 2006, Schedule 1, paragraph 13(3))
column6: POWER: To obtain and analyse data
column7: A CCG can obtain and analyse data or other information for any purpose connected with the exercise of its functions in relation to the health service. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 1, paragraph 13(3))
column10: POWER:  To provide premises, furniture or equipment
column11: Local authorities responsible for delivering social care services can provide premises, furniture or equipment to a CCG or NHS England for any of the purposes of the NHS Act 2006.  These purposes include the provision of NHS services and the promotion of public health. (NHS Act 2006, s254)
column14: POWER:  To provide premises, furniture or equipment
column15: Local authorities responsible for delivering social care services can provide premises, furniture or equipment to a CCG or NHS England for any of the purposes of the NHS Act 2006.  These purposes include the provision of NHS services and the promotion of public health. (NHS Act 2006, s254)

column2: DUTY:  To co-operate with NHS bodies when delivering care functions
column3:
A NHS England  must co-operate with local authorities and vice versa, when providing care services to adults, support services to carers and other related services
(Care Act 2014, section 6)
column6: DUTY: To co-operate with local authorities
column7: CCGs have a duty to cooperate with local authorities. (NHS Act 2006, s82)
column10: DUTY: To weigh and measure certain children
column11:
Regulations require local authorities to provide for the weighing and measuring of certain children in their area (including age and school type).

Information gained from weighing and measuring children can be processed by or on behalf of the local authority that carried out the exercise, with a view to using the information for research, monitoring, audit, the planning of services or any purpose connected with public health.  However, the information may only be disclosed in a way that means no child can be identified.

Note that there are particular rules about what NHS Digital can do with this information contained in the Local Authorities (Public Health, Health and Wellbeing Boards and Health Scrutiny) Regulations 2013, regulations 15 and 16.

(NHS Act 2006, Schedule 1, paragraph 7A, 7B, Local Authorities (Public Health Functions and Entry to Premises by Local Healthwatch Representatives) Regulations 2013, Part 2, Reg 3, Local Authorities (Public Health, Health and Wellbeing Boards and Health Scrutiny) Regulations 2013)
column14: POWER: To conduct research
column15: A local authority may conduct, commission or assist the conduct of research for any purpose connected with the exercise of its functions in relation to the health service. (Para 13 Sched 1 NHS Act 2006, s17(13) HSCA 2012)

column2: DUTY: To work with local authorities to improve the well-being of young children
column3:
NHS England has a duty to work with the local authority in connection with the authority’s arrangements for improving well-being etc. of young children.
(Children Act 2006, s4)
column6: POWER: To conduct research
column7:
A CCG may conduct, commission or assist the conduct of research into:

• any matters relating to the causation, prevention, diagnosis or treatment of illness; and
• any other matters connected with the health service that NHS England considers appropriate.

(NHS Act 2006, Schedule 1, para 13)
column10: POWER: To conduct research
column11: A local authority may conduct, commission or assist the conduct of research for any purpose connected with the exercise of its functions in relation to the health service. (Para 13 Sched 1 NHS Act 2006, s17(13) HSCA 2012)
column14: POWER: To obtain and analyse data
column15: A local authority can obtain and analyse data or other information for any purpose connected with the exercise of its functions in relation to the health service. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 1, paragraph 13(3))

column2: DUTY:  To help local authorities support children and families
column3:
NHS England has a duty to comply with any request from a local authority to help exercise any of its functions relating to support for children and families if compatible with the CCG’s own functions.
(Children Act 1989, s27)
column6: DUTY:  To co-operate with NHS bodies when delivering care functions
column7: A CCG must co-operate with local authorities in its area, and vice versa, when providing care services to adults, support services to carers and other related services (Care Act 2014, s6)
column10: POWER: To obtain and analyse data
column11: A local authority can obtain and analyse data or other information for any purpose connected with the exercise of its functions in relation to the health service. (NHS Act 2006, Schedule 1, paragraph 13(3))
column14: DUTY: To consider the economic, social and environmental benefits to be achieved through commissioning
column15: General duty on local authorities to consider the economic, environmental and social benefits that can be achieved through commissioning.  (Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012, section 1)

column2: DUTY: To make arrangements for safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children
column3: Duty for NHS England to make arrangements to ensure that when carrying out its functions regard is had to the need to safeguard and promote the welfare of children. (Children Act 2004 s11)
column6: DUTY: To work with local authorities regarding adoption services
column7: CCGs have a duty to work with local authorities in respect of the need to maintain adoption services via the provision of facilities for this purpose (Adoption and Children Act 2002, s4)
column10: DUTY:  To provide healthy start vitamins
column11: Local authorities must provide Healthy Start vitamins. (Healthy Start Scheme and Welfare Foods (Amendment) Regulations 2005, regulation 8A)

column2: DUTY: Eliminate discrimination, harassment and victimisation and advance equality of opportunity
column3:
Duty for NHS England to have due regard to the need to:

• eliminate unlawful discrimination, harassment and victimisation
• advance equality of opportunity between persons who share a relevant “protected characteristic” (e.g. ethnicity, gender) and persons who do not and
• foster good relations between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not.

(Equalities Act 2010, s149, schedule 19, part 1.)
column6: DUTY: To work with local authorities to improve the well-being of young children
column7:
CCGs have a duty to work with the local authority in connection with the authority’s arrangements for improving well-being etc. of young children.
(Childcare Act 2006, S4)
column10: DUTY: To consider the economic, social and environmental benefits to be achieved through commissioning
column11: General duty on local authorities to consider the economic, environmental and social benefits that can be achieved through commissioning.  (Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012, section 1)

column2: DUTY:  To share information
column3:
NHS England must share information about patients for whom it is responsible with other health and social care organisations involved in their care.  (There are various carve outs.)  Note that this provision does not enable the sharing of data that breaches the Data Protection Act 1998, the common law duty of confidence or the common law duty of care.
(Health and Social Care Act 2012, section 251B)
column6: DUTY:  To help local authorities support children and families
column7: A CCG has a duty to comply with any request from a local authority to help exercise any of its functions relating to support for children and families if compatible with the CCG’s own functions. (Children Act 1989, section 27)

column2: DUTY: To consider the economic, social and environmental benefits to be achieved through commissioning
column3:
General duty on NHS England to consider the economic, environmental and social benefits that can be achieved through commissioning.
(Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012, S1)
column6: DUTY: To make arrangements for safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children
column7:
Duty for CCGs to make arrangements for ensuring that when carrying out its functions regard is had to the need to safeguard and promote the welfare of children.
(Children Act 2004, s10)

column2: DUTY:  To provide healthy start vitamins
column3:
NHS England must arrange for the provision of Healthy Start vitamins if it provides, or arranges for the provision of, maternity services or a child health clinic.
(Healthy Start Scheme and Welfare Foods (Amendment) Regulations 2005, regulation 8A)
column6: DUTY: To reduce drug and alcohol abuse
column7: CCGs have a duty to work in co-operation with the police to formulate and implement a strategy to reduce the use of drugs, alcohol and other substances reduce reoffending and reduce crime and disorder (Crime and Disorder Act 1998, section 5)

column2: POWER: To enter into section 75 agreements with CCGs, providers and local authorities
column3:
NHS England can carry out the “health functions” and “health related functions” of a local authority, CCG NHS Trust, NHS Foundation Trust and vice versa if it enters into an agreement with that organisation that complies with the regulations. These agreements are often called section 75 agreements.

In practice this means that NHS England can carry out the functions of other organisations.

These arrangements can only be made in relation to health functions and health related functions.  These terms are defined in detail in the regulations.  Details of what functions are being carried out by which organisation will be contained in the section 75 agreement itself.

(NHS and Local Authorities Partnership Arrangements Regulations 2000)
column6: DUTY: To make arrangements for needs assessments for services after discharge
column7:
CCGs must make arrangements for an assessment of the needs of a long-term in-patients who have been receiving medical treatment for mental disorder, to inform the provision of services in relation to the discharge of a patient from hospital

(Disabled Persons (Services, Consultation and Representation) Act 1986, s7)

column2: POWER:  To enter in to and manage framework agreements for the purchase of services, drugs and medicines
column3:
NHS England may conclude and manage framework agreements to facilitate the purchase and supply of a service, drug, medicine or other substance or product that is provided as part of the health service.
(National Health Service Commissioning Board (Additional Functions) Regulations 2017, Regulation 4)
column6: DUTY:  To help local authorities deliver special educational needs services
column7: CCGs have a duty to assist a local authority in the discharge of its special educational needs functions at the request of the local authority. (Education Act 1996, s322)

column2: DUTY: To provide health service for prisoners
column3:
NHSCB must arrange, to the extent as it considers necessary to meet all reasonable requirements, provision of services for prisoners and other detainees
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) 2012, Part 3)
column6: DUTY: Eliminate discrimination, harassment and victimisation and advance equality of opportunity
column7:
Duty for CCGs to have due regard to the need to:

• eliminate unlawful discrimination, harassment and victimisation,
• advance equality of opportunity between persons who share a relevant “protected characteristic” (e.g. ethnicity, gender) and persons who do not and
• foster good relations between persons who share a relevant protected characteristic and persons who do not.

(Equalities Act 2010, s149, s19, part 1)

column2: DUTY: To provide community dental services
column3:
NHSCB must arrange, to the extent as it considers necessary to meet all reasonable requirements, provision of community dental services
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) 2012, Part 3)
column6: DUTY:  To share information
column7: CCGs must share information about patients for they are responsible with other health and social care organisations involved in their care.  (There are various carve outs.)  Note that this provision does not enable the sharing of data that breaches the Data Protection Act 1998, the common law duty of confidence or the common law duty of care. (Health and Social Care Act 2012, section 251B)

column2: DUTY: To provide health services to the armed forces
column3:
NHSCB must arrange, to the extent as it considers necessary to meet all reasonable requirements, provision of services for serving members of the armed forces and their families
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) 2012, Part 3)
column6: POWER: Be partnership organisations
column7: Ability for CCGs to second/ offer the services of CCG staff to local authorities and vice versa (Local Government Act 1972 s113 (1A))

column2: DUTY: To provide services for rare and very rare conditions
column3:
NHSCB must arrange, to the extent as it considers necessary to meet all reasonable requirements, provision of specified service for rare and very conditions; and
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) 2012, Part 3)
column6: POWER:  To partner with local authorities
column7: CCGs have the power to be partnership organisations of local authorities and are able to receive the services of local authorities officers  (Local Government Act 1972, section 113(1A))

column2: DUTY:  To provide mental health after care services
column3:
NHS England has a duty to arrange for the provision of mental health after care services if these fall within the services that NHS England must arrange under the NHS Act 2006.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, Part 4)
column6: DUTY:  To prepare a joint strategic needs assessment
column7:
CCGs must prepare a joint strategic needs assessment with the relevant local authority and a joint health and wellbeing strategy to meet those needs.
(Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007, section 116 & 116A)

column2: DUTY: Assessment and provisions of NHS continuing healthcare
column3:
When it is commissioning services NHS England has a duty to assess whether someone is eligible for a package of care funded by the NHS to meet physical or mental health needs which have arisen as a result of disability, accident or illness.

(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 21)
column6: DUTY: After care of patients with mental health problems
column7:
CCGs must, together with the local authority and relevant voluntary agencies, arrange for the provision of after care for people previously detained under the Mental Health Act, at the time that they cease to be detained. Such after care should be provided until the local social services authority is satisfied that such services are no longer required.
(Mental Health Act 1983 s117)

column2: DUTY:   Co-operation with social services regarding the provision of NHS continuing healthcare
column3:
NHS England must co-operate with the relevant local authority regarding continue healthcare services to patients.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 22
column6: DUTY: To consider the economic, social and environmental benefits to be achieved through commissioning
column7: General duty on CCGs to consider the economic, environmental and social benefits that can be achieved through commissioning.  (Public Services (Social Value) Act 2012, s1)

column2: DUTY:  Arrangement of personal health budgets
column3:
NHS England must ensure that it is able to arrange personal health budgets for the delivery of NHS continuing healthcare.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 32B)
column6: DUTY:  To provide healthy start vitamins
column7: CCGs must arrange for the provision of Healthy Start vitamins if it provides, or arranges for the provision of, maternity services or a child health clinic. (Healthy Start Scheme and Welfare Foods (Amendment) Regulations 2005, regulation 8A)

column2: DUTY:  To ensure that patients requiring an elective referral are offered a choice of provider
column3:
NHS England must ensure that patients for whom it is responsible for commissioning care and who need an elective referral are given a choice of provider.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 39)
column6: DUTY:  To comply with NICE technology appraisal recommendations
column7: CCGs must comply with a technology appraisal recommendation made by the National Institute for Health & Care Excellence (National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Constitution and Functions) and the Health and Social Care Information Centre (Functions) Regulations 2013)

column2: DUTY:  To make arrangements to meet waiting times standards
column3:
NHS England must make arrangements to meet the waiting times targets.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 45)
column6: DUTY:   Assessment and provision of NHS continuing healthcare
column7: When it is commissioning services a CCG has a duty to assess whether someone is eligible for a package of care funded by the NHS to meet physical or mental health needs which have arisen as a result of disability, accident or illness; (NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 21)

column2: DUTY:  To make arrangements to offer an alternative provider
column3:
NHS England must offer an alternative provider in some circumstances
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulations 48 and 53.)
column6: DUTY:   Co-operation with social services regarding the provision of NHS continuing healthcare
column7:
CCGs must co-operate with the relevant local authority regarding continue healthcare services to patients.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 22)

column2: DUTY:  To make arrangements for urgent cancer appointments
column3:
NHS England must make arrangements to meet the waiting times targets for cancer treatment.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 52)
column6: DUTY:  Arrangement of personal health budgets
column7:
CCGs must ensure that they are able to arrange personal health budgets for the delivery of NHS continuing healthcare
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 32B)

column2: DUTY: To ensure buying decisions are fair and improve quality and efficiency of healthcare services
column3:
Decisions made by NHS England about the purchase of healthcare services (excluding pharmaceutical services) must be transparent and fair, and improve the quality and efficiency of healthcare services for patients. In particular NHS England must act with a view to:

• (a) Securing the needs of the people who use the services
• (b) Improving the quality of the services
• (c) Improving efficiency in the provisions of the services.

(NHS (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No.2) Regulations 2013)
column6: DUTY:  To ensure that patients requiring an elective referral are offered a choice of provider
column7:
A CCG must ensure that patients for whom it is responsible for commissioning care and who need an elective referral are given a choice of provider.  (There are some carve outs at regulation 40 and 41.)
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 39)

column6: DUTY:  To make arrangements to meet waiting times standards
column7:
A CCG must make arrangements to meet the waiting times targets.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 45)

column6: DUTY:  To make arrangements to offer an alternative provider
column7:
A CCG must offer an alternative provider in some circumstances.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 48, 53 (suspected cancer))

column6: DUTY:  To make arrangements for urgent cancer appointments
column7:
A CCG must make arrangements to meet the waiting times targets for cancer treatment.
(NHS Commissioning Board and Clinical Commissioning Groups (Responsibilities and Standing Rules) Regulations 2012, regulation 52)

column6: DUTY: To ensure buying decisions are fair and improve quality and efficiency of healthcare services
column7:
Decisions made by CCGs about the purchase of healthcare services (excluding pharmaceutical services) must be transparent and fair, and improve the quality and efficiency of healthcare services for patients. In particular CCGs must act with a view to:

• Securing the needs of the people who use the services;
• Improving the quality of the services; and
• Improving efficiency in the provisions of the services.

(NHS (Procurement, Patient Choice and Competition) (No.2) Regulations 2013)
